posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
Link to the model:

https://makerworld.com/en/models/811866#profileId-753396

So yesterday as I was reading this thread

Affordable Charuco Calibration Targets General Forum

I thought I have a 3D the printer that is capable of printing multiple colour. If I could use it to make a Calibration target it will be interesting.

After importing the original PDF from PhotonVision to Inkscape I was able to convert the pattern to SVG, then using SVG 2 STL I was able to make a STL for the pattern. After importing it to the slicer and assemble it with a square base plate and some colouring, I got my sliced file.

Screenshot 2024-11-23 at 20.24.00 1834Ã—1342 103 KB

Screenshot 2024-11-23 at 20.24.00 1834Ã—1342 103 KB

Screenshot 2024-11-23 at 20.24.00 1834Ã—1342 103 KB

The print quality come out pretty good. When the printed part remain on the print plate, it remain flat (which is good for calibration), and the scale seems ok.

IMG_9717 1920Ã—2560 241 KB

IMG_9717 1920Ã—2560 241 KB

IMG_9717 1920Ã—2560 241 KB

When I remove it from the print plate it do wrap, making the whole print bent. This is not acceptable for calibrating camera.

Screenshot 2024-11-23 at 20.26.08 832Ã—868 59.5 KB

Screenshot 2024-11-23 at 20.26.08 832Ã—868 59.5 KB

Screenshot 2024-11-23 at 20.26.08 832Ã—868 59.5 KB

Here are some of the issues:

The only way to ensure the flatness is to have it remain on the print bad and use the print bed as a carrier. Print bed tends to lose a adhesion overtime and not everyone had a spare print bed. I want to try putting some double-sided tape and fix it to another flat plate oo see how well it hold.

just in case if multicolour printing is impossible, I want to try use a sharpie to colour the whole thing black and see how well it work.

IMG_9720 1920Ã—2560 242 KB

IMG_9720 1920Ã—2560 242 KB

IMG_9720 1920Ã—2560 242 KB

If anyone have any suggestion, please.

A manual filament swap should also work fine for this. I know PrusaSlicer makes it pretty easy to add a pause between layers to switch out filament for multicolor print.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
NathanZhou:

some of the issues

Iâ€™ll add to the list as I donâ€™t understand how this can work with the commonly available calibration calculations. With the slight height of the squares, only straight-on are the dimensions correct and actually everything will be slightly off center and will see the side of the height as a change in width. Iâ€™ll be interested to know how well these calibrate compared to a flatter piece of paper. In this age of fussing about 1/2 a pixel Iâ€™m guessing these wonâ€™t work right.

There are (expensive) 3-D calibration targets and Iâ€™m sure they would require different calculations.

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: I really feel like this is an application for a 2D printer.

posts.name: Joey Tidrow
posts.cooked: It can be made on a 2d printer but the goal of this is for it to be very flat and most 2d printers can only take in a flexible paper like material that does not come out flat. You could tape that paper to a flat board like I have in the past but this is to try to make a better solution that does not suffer from the paper stretching and not becoming flat on the board anymore.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Arrowmag:

try to make a better solution that does not suffer from the paper stretching and not becoming flat on the board anymore.

Very interestingâ€¦

[throws on PhotonVision Dev Hat]

The current cal recommendations talk about making sure the target is very flat. We owe a docs update to make this more specific, but the best practices weâ€™ve found so far (in order from best to worse) are:

A matte laptop screen or modern computer monitor (the manufacturing process causes a pretty solid guarantee of flatness)

A purpose-made calibration target with a nice stiff backing

Printed target, measured and double-checked for accuracy with a calipers, and spray-adhesived onto a backing that is known to be flat.

[throws on mentor hat]

This is because the underlying calibration logic, currently, is hard-coded to assume all black/white quad corners lie in a 2d plane. Making them not in a plane (especially a consistently warped plane) has the effect of throwing off the lens distortion model coefficients, with (anecdotally) very unpredictable results.

Sometimes itâ€™s obvious, sometimes it might just be inducing a random few-inches error in your pose estimate. Weâ€™ve yet to figure out how to predict goodness here.

Iâ€™d have concerns with a 3d print over warping (esp. for a full-bed size print), and the fact (at least my) PEI textured bed is visibly less flat than any of the above recommended solutions.

[throws on PhotonVision Dev Hat]

A 3d printed target wouldnâ€™t show up in the recommended list until it could be shown same-as-or-better-than one of the options on the listâ€¦ and Iâ€™m not entirely sure how to prove that for all teamâ€™s 3d printers. Or even for 1 teamâ€™s 3d printer.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
gerthworm:

corners

(The corners actually being sharp right angles is also important for the detection algorithm, and because of the FDM process this just isnâ€™t possible)

A 3d printed target wouldnâ€™t show up in the recommended list until it could be shown same-as-or-better-than one of the options on the listâ€¦ and Iâ€™m not entirely sure how to prove that for all teamâ€™s 3d printers. Or even for 1 teamâ€™s 3d printer.

So after serival experiments I would say this is pretty true. The effort / money required is much more than a paper glued on glass or laptop display.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked:
Due to how glass is made, it tends to be quite flat while being relatively cheap. Importantly, it doesnâ€™t like to bend. At all. Metal and plastic donâ€™t really do the same. (acrylic is brittle but bends a lot more than glass does) Iâ€™m not sure about whiteboards which would be my other go-to idea.

Print it out on a standard printer, cover the back with glue, and use a paint roller to get it on there good. Alternatively, you could straight up etch it in the glass if you have a decent laser cutter.
